article:
'Personal boundaries' are guidelines, rules or limits that a person creates to
identify for him- or herself what are reasonable, safe and permissible ways for
other people to behave around him or her and how he or she will respond when
someone steps outside those
limits. [http://www.outofthefog.net/CommonNonBehaviors/Boundaries.html
Boundaries definition], Outofthefog.net They are built out of a mix of
beliefs, opinions, attitudes, past experiences and social learning. Vanessa
Rogers, Working with Young Men (2010) p. 80

Personal boundaries define you as an individual, outlining your likes and
dislikes, and setting the distances you allow others to approach. G. B. and
J. S. Lundberg, I Don't Have to Make Everything All Better (2000) p. 13. ISBN
978-0-670-88485-8 They include physical, mental, psychological and
spiritual boundaries, involving beliefs, emotions, intuitions and self-
esteem. Timothy Porter-O'Grady/Kathy Malloch, Quantum Leadership (2003) p.
135 Jacques Lacan considered them to be layered in a hierarchy, reflecting
âall the successive envelopes of the biological and social status of the
personâ Jacques Lacan, Ecrits (1997) p. 16-7 from the most primitive
to the most advanced.
